message.raw:
As per BLACS [issue #13](#!/labscript_suite/blacs/issues/13/launch-blacs-as-a-secondary-control-system), this code provides a new syntax for defining the connections to remote workers and secondary control systems.

The syntax should be used as `SecondaryControlSystem('control2', 'bec-control2.physics.monash.edu:42518')` to define the connection to the secondary control system (similarly for remote worker brokers). To use this, then modify your usual device instantiation as so `NovaTechDDS9M('novatech1', my_clockline, com_port = control2('com14'))`

message.raw:
Added kwards "start_order" and "stop_order" at the base Device() object.  These
are enforced to be integer in the range ORDER_MINIMUM to ORDER_MAXIMUM that
are defined constants.  This is the first part of providing the functionality
of programming devices in different batches grouped by their device order.  These
will be saved into the device properties, and used by blacs.

message.raw:
fixes issue #40

* We now quantise all times to multiples of the pseudoclock clock_resolution.
* changed some error messages to report times, and to report the times to more significant figures so it is easy to see if the discrepancy comes from floating point rounding error)
* Added a method to `Device` which allows you to quantise times based on the clock_resolution of the parent pseudoclock device.
message.html:

  • changed some error messages to report times, and to report the times to more significant figures so it is easy to see if the discrepancy comes from floating point rounding error)
  • Added a method to Device which allows you to quantise times based on the clock_resolution of the parent pseudoclock device.

message.raw:
Save Mercurial revision data of labscript file in h5 file instead of SVN.
Seems appropriate as we migrated labscript source to Mercurial in January 2013.
Chances are that most user side code, e.g. labscript_suite/userlib/labscriptlib
will be under Mercurial control, as has been the case @ Monash since June 2014.

message.raw:
Omitted the truncate decorator in favour of changing every ramp method.
Now the duration is modified before add_instruction is executed.
This is more maintainable in the long run, as it is immune to changes to Output.
It also avoids the ramp collision detection problem.
Minor changes to exp_ramp and exp_ramp_t to conform with kwarg name(s) and error
checking.

message.raw:
Added truncation decorator for ramp functions. Allows a truncation kwarg to be
passed to decorated ramp functions, whose effect is to keep the same functional
form of the ramp, but truncate the duration by a fraction between 0 and 1.
This works by modifying the end_time of the instruction generated by the ramp,
prior to sampling. One issue with this implementation is that the collision
detection of ramps in add_instruction uses the end_time of the full ramp, which
cannot be readily circumvented.

message.raw:
Fixed bug where the ClockLine clock_limits were not taken into account when determining the minimum time between a wait and subsequent output.
This meant that triggers to secondary pseudoclocks, immediately followed by output could be faster than the allowed update rate of IntermediateDevices. This was fortunately caught further down the line, but should have never been a problem.

The wait() function (via a fix to trigger_all_pseudoclocks) now returns the correct length of time before you can command further output.

It is possible this bug only affected wait() commands with a single pseudoclock where the pseudoclock trigger_duration was very short and the wait_monitor was on a clockline that had a high clock_limit.

message.raw:
Fixed bug where all wait timeouts were set to the timeout of the first wait.

This was due to a list comprehension leaking values into the namespace of the wait() function because we used a variable name in the list comprehension which was the same as one of the function arguments.
The list comprehension has been modified to use a dummy variable name

message.raw:
Fixes and changes to properties (previously referred to as generic attributes)

Implemented serialisation at several points:
    - Connection table properties and unit conversion parameters are both now
      serialised unconditionally using JSON.
    - Device properties are now written in write_device_properties, which is
      called from stop(), rather than earlier during init_device_group.
      This is so that device code can call self.set_property(... location='device_properties')
      after init_device_group (which now doesn't do much) and still have these
      be written to the file.
    - Renamed 'destination' to 'location' everyhwere (more meaningful for 'get')
    - This code relies on serialisation and deserialisation code in labscript_utils.properties.

Fixed a bug where added_properties was passed into the decorator by itself
rather than as a list; 'in' checks still passed, as all strings are substrings
of themselves, but this would produce broken behaviour in other cases.

rather than as a list; 'in' checks still passed, as all strings are substrings
of themselves, but this would produce broken behaviour in other cases.

message.raw:
On the basis of converesations with the Monash team, I have revised the
properties decorator to be much more general.  Currently device is setup to
expect properties set by the instantian attribute:

    valid_property_destinations = {"con_table_properties", "device_properties"}

so a viable function call might look like (from Camera):

    @set_passed_properties(
        property_names = {
            "con_table_properties": ["BIAS_port"],
            "device_properties": ["serial_number", "SDK", "effective_pixel_size", "exposuretime", "orientation", "trigger_edge_type", "minimum_recovery_time", "added_properties"]}
        )
    def __init__(self, name, parent_device, connection,
                 BIAS_port = 1027, serial_number = 0x0, SDK='', effective_pixel_size=0.0,
                 exposuretime=None, orientation='side', trigger_edge_type='rising', minimum_recovery_time=0,
                 **kwargs):

We see several things here:
(1) the destination of any property is limited by the options defined in
        valid_property_destinations. This can be altered in child objects, but
        it would lead to problems if we do not create a superset of what is in
        Device.

(2) We have two destinations by default: information that is sent to the
        properties entry of the connection table, and information that is sent
        to the device.  !!! I have not written code that actually writes this!!!

(3) Digging into the code you will find that Device.__init__ now takes the
        named argument "added_properties" which can be absolutly anything the
        user wants in the "device_properties" propties.  These are assumed
        to have no special meaning within labscript proper, but is there
        to provide extra information.  For example, to configure the camera
        in labview, where different cameras want quite different information.

message.raw:
Created a new branch to add the ability of the user to pass arbitarary config
attributes to any device.  This involves some effort to pass **kwargs in
__init__ all the way up to the root Device class.  Part of this will/may
have me writing attributes to a new "Config" group in the device group in the
h5 file, so I will also be moving the code which creates the individual
device group into the root __init__ as well.

message.raw:
Fixed bug that broke default values for Static outputs

When filling the raw_output array, you should access the value through the class property static_value so that it can be set to the default value for the class if it has not been explicitly set during the users experiment logic.

message.raw:
Fixed bug with dtype

Channels that were held constant while their parent clockline ramped another channel did not preserve the dtype of the value. Instead of forcing the value to float32 always, we now respect the dtype stored for the channel.
